#Dyspnea
Patient admitted from ___ with concern for new pneumonia 
initially in the setting of dyspnea and possible new oxygen 
requirement. She was afebrile with normal WBC count, no cough 
and CXR without clear pneumonia or edema. She was rapidly weaned 
from 2L NC to room air. She was maintained on oxygen for comfort 
(100%RA when trialed off) however this was weaned after diuresis 
as below and treatment of anemia. 

#Moderate Protein-Calorie Malnutrition
Patient with history of malnutrition and complicated ICU course 
in ___. On this admission, she was noted to have 
markedly depressed albumin with anasarca consistent with 
malnutrition. Etiology of her malnutrition was felt to be 
multifactorial related to chronic multifactorial abdominal pain 
(extensively worked-up previously with multiple causes, stable 
currently), inability to take significant POs following RYGB in 
___, poor absorption post-bypass, pain and decreased appetite 
related to anasarca and underlying anxiety/depression. We 
discussed starting an appetite stimulant with the patient and 
her family who were interested in this option and she was 
started on mirtazapine which was uptitrated to 15mg qhs. She had 
some improvement in PO intake with mirtazapine however given 
degree of malnutrition, nutrition felt she was likely going to 
be unable to meet her caloric needs and rebuild her nutritional 
status without nutritional assistance. ___ (___) was placed 
via EGD by GI on ___. Tube feeds were started on ___ and 
cycled started on ___. Initially Ms. ___ had some vomiting 
after starting to cycle the feeds, so the feeds were changed 
back to continuous for ___. The feeds were changed again to 
cycled on ___, this time increasing the rate to goal more 
slowly, and this time she tolerated it well without any nausea 
or vomiting. Plan is for tube feeds for ___ weeks pending 
nutritional status and improved PO intake (improving prior to 
discharge). Cycled tube feeds for 12 hours daily to reach 71% of 
daily caloric needs. 

#Anasarca
#Total body pain

She will need ongoing lasix at discharge 20 mg PO daily and

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

You were admitted to the hospital with shortness of breath, 
malnutrition and a UTI. 

Your urinary tract infection was treated with antibiotics with 
improvement in your symptoms. 

Your shortness of breath was felt to be due to extra fluid on 
your body causing swelling due to malnutrition and a low albumin 
level. You were started on a new medication called mirtazapine 
to help with your appetite. You also had a dobhoff (feeding 
tube) placed temporarily to help improve your nutrition while 
the new medication takes effect. 

For the extra fluid in your body, you were treated with lasix 
with decreased swelling. You will continue to take this 
medication by mouth after discharge to continue to get fluid out 
of your body. 

You are being discharged to a different rehab, CareOne, where 
they can help with your tube feeds. 

It was a pleasure taking care of you,
Your ___ Care Team
